sen.j: 質取行為（しちとりこうい）とは、中世日本において、別の地域に住む債務者から弁済を受けられなかった債権者が、債務者と同一の地域に住む第三者（債務者との面識の有無は問わず）の身柄あるいは財物を債務の賠償として私的に差し押さえる行為。
sen.e: In the Middle Ages in Japan Shichitorikoi was an action of a creditor, who could not receive compensation from a debtor living in a different region, arresting a third person who lived in the same region as the creditor (whether the person is acquainted with the debtor or not) and privately confiscating his/her properties as compensation for the debt.

In the medieval Japan, Shichitorikoi was an action of a creditor, who could not receive compensation from a debtor living in a different region, to capture a third person who lived in the same region as the creditor (regardless of whether the person is acquainted with the debtor or not) or to privately confiscate the person's properties as compensation for the debt.

In the medieval Japan, Shichitorikoi was an action of a creditor, who could not receive compensation from a debtor living in a different region, to capture a third person who lived in the same region as the creditor (regardless of whether the person is acquainted with the debtor or not) or to privately confiscate the person's properties as compensation for the debt.

sen.j: また訴訟の当事者が係争相手と同一の地域に住む第三者に対して行われる場合もある。
sen.e: Sometimes the accuser (creditor) sued a third person who lived in the same region as the accused (debtor).

sen.e: In this case, different terms were used depending on where it took place.

sen.e: This is said to have been due to group responsibility/collective responsibility imposed on people with blood relationship in a clan society that changed into a common law accompanied by the collapse of a clan society and social shaping by territorial connections.

sen.j: 特に守護領国制や郷村制の形成が進んだ南北朝時代_(日本)以後によく見られるようになった。
sen.e: It was often seen in and after the Nanbokucho (Northern and Southern Dynasties) period (Japan) with the advanced formation of the Shugo-ryogoku system and the goson-sei (system of coalitions of villages).

sen.j: なお、問題の行為が殺人であったりした場合には仇討・復讐の一環として下手人の代わりに質取対象者の生命を差し押さえて没収する行為も「質取行為」として正当なものとされていた。
sen.e: Even in the case of murder, as part adauchi (revenge including killing)/fukushu (revenge) the act of shichitori of arresting or killing a person for shichitori, instead of a murderer, was justified.
Even in the case of murder, seizing and taking a debtor's life instead of a murderer's as a part of adauchi (revenge including killing)/fukushu (revenge) was justified as a way of Shichitorikoi.

sen.j: 室町幕府や戦国大名なども市場や道路などのいわゆる「アジール」的な場所での質取行為は禁止したものの、前述の地縁に関する認識の存在と慣習法としての一般認識の存在、他に債務者に対して債務返済への心理的圧力としてある程度までは有効性があったことから、規制は行われても禁止にまで踏み切った法は存在しなかった。
sen.e: The Muromachi bakufu and warring lords banned shichitori acts in so-called sanctuary-like places such as markets and streets, which had some effectiveness to restrict the existence of the above-mentioned cognition of territorial connection, the existence of general cognition as a common law and to give some mental pressure to the creditor asking the debtor to pay the debt, however, there was no law to ban the acts.

While the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) banned Shichitorikoi in so-called sanctuary-like places such as markets and streets, there were only restrictions and was no law to ban the actions because Shichitorikoi was effective as the existence of the above-mentioned cognition of the group responsibility in a local community and the general cognition as a common law and mental pressure on the debtor to pay for his or her debt.
